question_details.query: When managing pastureland for natural pest control, is it better to delay mowing/grazing or to use grazing instead of cutting?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on delaying mowing/first grazing shows mixed or neutral effects on natural enemies and pests: one replicated, randomised, controlled study found fewer predatory spiders with delayed cutting; other UK studies found no change in insect predator numbers; a Swedish study found mixed effects between predator groups; pest insects were higher in late-cut plots in one UK/USA study and unchanged in another (ID: 727). Additional studies report that delaying mowing/grazing increased some natural enemy groups (greater abundance of some spiders and ground beetles) and more insect species/individuals visiting flowers in some cases, while other studies found no clear effect on some insects and spiders (ID: 131). Using grazing instead of cutting also shows mixed outcomes: effects on natural enemies varied by species/date with one study finding no effect; among five studies on pests/diseases, one found more pests, two found effects varied by pest group/date, and two found no effect; one study found no effect on disease when grazing was used in addition to cutting (ID: 885).

question_details.query: What are the overall effects of altering pesticide application strategies to benefit natural enemies?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence indicates several pesticide strategy changes can increase natural enemies, though effects often vary by group, time and context. Spraying insecticides earlier in the season was associated with more natural enemies in one UK study [723]. Using threshold-based spraying increased natural enemy numbers in two of three years in a Finnish study, with effects lasting as little as three weeks [750]. Delaying herbicide applications increased natural enemies in two randomized, replicated, controlled trials, though benefits differed among enemy groups and were fewer early in the season [774]. Broad reductions in chemical inputs often benefited invertebrates, but multiple studies also reported mixed, minimal or no effects [139]; specifically for butterflies and moths, reduced or less frequent chemical inputs were frequently linked to higher richness and/or abundance, with some studies finding similar levels to conventional management [3897]. Incorporating parasitism rates into insecticide thresholds produced acceptable pest damage levels, but effects on natural enemy populations were not monitored [726]. Experimental conversions to organic farming often increased natural enemies in 8 of 12 studies, but several studies found no, inconsistent or negative effects, and responses varied by enemy group and over time [717].

statement_judgements.statement: Evidence indicates several pesticide strategy changes can increase natural enemies.
statement_judgements.reasoning: The context provides multiple examples of pesticide strategy changes leading to increased natural enemies. Specifically, 'Alter the timing of insecticide use' (723) mentions 'more natural enemies when insecticides were sprayed earlier'. 'Use pesticides only when pests or crop damage reach threshold levels' (750) states 'threshold-based spraying regimes increased numbers of natural enemies'. 'Delay herbicide use' (774) notes 'more natural enemies when herbicide treatments were delayed'. Lastly, 'Convert to organic farming' (717) indicates 'Eight of 12 studies ... found more natural enemies under organic farming'. Therefore, several distinct strategy changes are supported as increasing natural enemies.

question_details.query: When planting non-crop vegetation to enhance natural pest control, what is the comparative evidence for planting new hedges versus plants that attract natural enemies with chemicals?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Plants that produce attractive chemicals: Four studies from China, Germany, India and Kenya tested planting non-crop plants that emit chemicals attractive to natural enemies; three (including one replicated, randomised, controlled trial) found higher numbers of natural enemies or attraction in lab studies, one found no effect on parasitism when the plant used was not attractive in lab tests; all four studies found reduced pest populations or damage; one replicated, randomised, controlled study reported increased crop yield; crops studied included lettuce, orange, safflower and sorghum [724]. Hedges: One randomised, replicated, controlled study from China found no effect of hedges on spider numbers in crops; of two studies from France and China, one found more natural enemies in hedges than adjacent crops while one found effects varied by crop type, hedge species and year; two randomised, replicated, controlled studies from France and Kenya found natural enemy abundance in hedges depended on shrub/tree species and varied among enemy groups; one randomised, replicated, controlled study from Kenya on fallow plots found pest (nematode) effects varied between nematode groups; crops studied included barley, beans, maize and wheat [752].

question_details.query: What are the potential negative impacts on crops when incorporating plant remains into the soil to control weeds?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies of allelopathic plant residues incorporated into soil, crop growth was sometimes inhibited (two of three studies) [728]. Yield responses included negative or mixed effects when compared with weeded controls (three randomized, replicated, controlled studies), indicating that yields were sometimes reduced under this practice [728]. Additional drawbacks reported alongside crop performance outcomes included short-lived weed suppression (lasting only days to weeks after incorporation) [728] and mixed effects on pests [728].

summary_statements: Across studies of allelopathic plant residues incorporated into soil, crop growth was sometimes inhibited.
Yield responses included negative or mixed effects when compared with weeded controls, indicating that crop yields were sometimes reduced when allelopathic plant residues were incorporated into soil.
When plant remains were incorporated into the soil, short-lived weed suppression was an additional drawback reported alongside crop performance outcomes.
When plant remains were incorporated into the soil, mixed effects on pests were also reported as a drawback.

This confirms that negative and mixed effects were observed in comparison to weeded controls. Thus, all parts of the statement are supported.
